report_title: Beer, Wine & Liquor Stores in the US
executive_summary: Beer, wine and liquor stores have remained in high spirits over the past five years despite some uncharacteristic volatility. A rise in disposable income levels has boosted sales of high-margin and imported beverages, typically less available at alternative retailers. Consumer preferences have shifted away from popular global beer brands to local craft styles with high-quality ingredients and higher profit margins. A rise in e-commerce has encouraged many stores to incorporate online orders and delivery, boosting sales among younger demographics. Over the past five years, revenue for beer, wine and liquor stores has been expanding at a CAGR of 2.2% and is expected to rise 2.9% in 2024 alone, when sales will reach $79.9 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The coronavirus precipitated a surge in demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The coronavirus precipitated a surge in demand for alcohol from liquor stores as bars and restaurants were forced to close. Consumers' drinking habits shifted to favor off-premise drinking, with canned and ready-to-drink cocktails becoming particularly popular during the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Deregulation across states has expanded competition
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: However, deregulation across states has expanded competition from other retailers, mitigating liquor stores' sales, particularly as on-premise establishments reopened in the pandemic's wake. Supermarkets and wholesale clubs have emerged as fierce competitors as they leverage their large operations to secure lower prices from suppliers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth opportunities through e-commerce and new products
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While competition is set to intensify over the next five years, beer, wine and liquor stores will find growth opportunities through e-commerce and new product offerings, like canned cocktails. Rising disposable income levels will encourage consumers to purchase more premium, high-margin alcohols, supporting profit.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Deregulation is Set to Heighten Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, more states will continue deregulating beer, wine and liquor retail as state budgetary concerns put pressure on state-run liquor stores. Looser regulations will prompt the emergence of new liquor stores, intensifying internal competition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: E-COMMERCE WILL DRIVE LIQUOR STORES FORWARD
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Online sales are set to become an increasingly large share of liquor stores' sales over the next five years. Liquor stores with mobile platforms will be better positioned to reach young adults. As consumers get busier and hybrid work policies encourage geographic flexibility, liquor stores with online capabilities will become more appealing to modern consumers and will generate more revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SHIFTING PREFERENCES PRESENT OPPORTUNITIES AND THREATS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The coronavirus boosted the popularity of premixed cocktails, which include ready-to-drink hard seltzers and gin and tonics. These products are especially popular among younger consumers. Canned cocktails represent a significant opportunity for liquor stores since regulations on the sale of spirits mean that they are difficult to find outside of beer, wine and liquor stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Liquor Stores Embrace Innovation and Personalization
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Creating unique experiences for shoppers will be crucial to maintain foot traffic to liquor stores over the next five years as large-scale retailers siphon demand. Beer, wine and liquor stores will leverage technology like augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) to enhance the shopping experience and allow customers to explore products virtually.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry include retail stores specifically licensed to sell packaged alcoholic beverages, including beer, wine and liquor, for off-premises consumption.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Supermarkets have become a significant substitute for traditional liquor stores. As more states relax alcohol sale laws, supermarkets are expanding their offerings, providing convenience for customers purchasing groceries and alcohol in one trip.

DIY alcoholic beverage production is rising, spurred by a growing interest in home brewing, winemaking and distilling. This trend accelerated during the coronavirus pandemic, driving demand for DIY kits and supplies.

Online sales are promoting industry consolidation and expansion. E-commerce enables stores to reach broader audiences, prompting smaller retailers to merge for efficiency or invest in digital infrastructure, thereby driving market consolidation.

Increasing disposable income has driven sales of high-margin and premium imported beverages. Additionally, consumer preferences are leaning towards local craft styles, which offer higher quality ingredients and profit compared to global brands.

Despite rising competition from supermarkets and wholesale clubs, beer, wine and liquor stores can leverage e-commerce and new product offerings to sustain growth. Increasing disposable incomes and excise tax reductions will further support revenue by encouraging premium alcohol purchases.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market includes consumers between the ages of 21 and 44. Younger demographics are driving a trend away from heavy alcohol consumption as health consciousness pushes sober curiosity. Though they are drinking less than their older age cohorts, younger consumers prefer higher-quality beverages, particularly those in Generation Z. Premiumization within this age group has inflated sales of craft beers, wines and spirits.

This segment includes consumers between the ages of 45 and 64. This demographic has warmed up to premiumization, with aged liquors and high-margin brands of wine being particularly popular with these consumers. Consumers in this segment are more financially established than their younger counterparts and are more likely to host social gatherings with beer, wine and spirits.

This segment includes consumers aged 65 and older. Some older consumers exclusively purchase alcohol at restaurants and other on-premise drinking sites. Still, this segment consists of a sizeable share of revenue. Alcohol consumption drops precipitously upon retirement age, making this age group a consistently small market for liquor stores. This market has dwindled slightly as the younger market has expanded over the past five years.

This market includes retailers, wholesalers, businesses, restaurants, hotels and other food service establishments. While many of these businesses still use traditional channels, e-commerce has become an increasingly popular way to obtain alcohol.

products_and_services.product_description: The spirit segment includes the largest variety of alcoholic beverages, including vodka, gin, rum, whiskey and many other spirits. Spirits are typically more costly than beer and certain wines.

The wine segment includes all varieties of wine, ranging from Pinot Grigio to Merlot and dessert wines. While wine is typically costlier than beer, many value brands are available and most consumers still with bottles under a certain price point.
The beer segment includes the vast varieties of beer, ranging from traditional American lagers to imported brands and niche offerings from local craft brewers and microbreweries.
This segment includes tobacco products, bottle openers, magazines, snacks and soft drinks. These products tend to grow in popularity during certain times of the year, like summers and the holidays.

tier_1_suppliers: Wine & Spirits Wholesaling in the US
Soft Drink, Baked Goods & Other Grocery Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Tank & Refrigeration Trucking in the US
tier_1_buyers: Accommodation and Food Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: When per capita disposable income rises, consumers tend to spend more on discretionary goods like alcohol. This increased income also often leads to higher spending on higher-margin products and premium brands. Conversely, when financial constraints tighten, consumers are more likely to opt for cost-efficient alternatives or reduce their discretionary purchases, impacting the sales of more expensive alcohol options.

business_locations.location_description: With states like Florida and Georgia, the Southeast region boasts a large and growing population, creating significant demand for alcohol retail stores. Florida's tourism-driven economy also boosts sales, further supporting the high number of stores in the region. Economic growth and disposable income levels in Southern states contribute to increased consumer spending on alcohol, encouraging more store openings. Areas like Atlanta and Miami benefit from affluent consumers, bolstering their liquor retail markets. Several states in the Southeast have relatively relaxed alcohol licensing laws compared to stricter regions, making it easier for entrepreneurs to enter the market. This regulatory friendliness spurs business growth, leading to a higher concentration of stores. The Southeast's diverse culture and vibrant social scene drive demand for a wide range of alcoholic beverages. From craft breweries in North Carolina to coastal wineries in Virginia, the variety of preferences supports numerous specialized and general alcohol retail outlets.

The Mid-Atlantic region, with densely populated states like New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, offers a high consumer base driving demand for beer, wine and liquor stores. This concentration of potential customers supports a more significant number of retail outlets. The region's diverse demographics, including urban and suburban communities, create varied consumer preferences and spending habits. This diversity encourages the establishment of numerous stores to cater to different tastes and income levels. Compared to more restrictive areas, favorable regulatory environments in parts of the Mid-Atlantic make it easier for businesses to obtain licenses and operate efficiently. This regulatory support fosters a thriving market for alcohol retailers. The region's robust transportation and distribution networks facilitate easier store supply chain management. Efficient logistics, including proximity to major ports and highways, enable quicker restocking and a steady flow of products, supporting a high density of stores.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US operates under a complex three-tier system separating the production, distribution and retail of alcohol, with each state setting its own laws. This creates a varied operational environment for store owners dealing with different state rules, impacting supply chains, pricing and product variety.

Federal law requires alcohol sales to individuals aged 21 or over, necessitating rigorous ID verification processes in retail settings. Retailers face heavy fines, license loss, or even criminal charges for non-compliance; hence, investing in ID scanning technology and continuous staff training becomes crucial.

Alcohol advertising is strictly regulated to avoid appealing to minors, with limits on media types and messaging content. This constrains retail stores' promotional strategies; they can't use certain creative elements like cartoon characters and must avoid underage-targeted media, thereby relying more on localized and word-of-mouth marketing efforts, complicating advertising campaigns.

Alcohol faces multiple excise taxes and sometimes minimum pricing regulations to prevent discounting. These taxes influence pricing strategies and reduce profit, as retailers must navigate a complex tax structure.

Retailers must meet health and safety standards for storing and handling alcohol products. Non-compliance can lead to penalties and damage to reputation due to compromised product quality. This regulation requires investment in adequate storage infrastructure and continuous staff training, ensuring products remain in optimal condition, adding to operational costs and securing consumer trust.

E-commerce growth introduces varied state laws on online alcohol sales and delivery, with many states setting ambiguous or stringent guidelines. Retailers expanding into online markets face regulatory hurdles differing widely by state.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Regulations are high for operators in the Beer, Wine and Liquor Stores industry as many states restrict who can own and operate a liquor store, and the process of obtaining a license can be time-consuming and costly.
Setting up a liquor store can be expensive, requiring a significant investment in inventory, equipment and retail space.

New beer, wine and liquor stores may find it difficult to compete with established retailers that have brand recognition and a loyal customer base, needing to differentiate based on price or product and service offerings.
Liquor stores require substantial labor to stock shelves, manage inventory and provide customer service, with challenges in finding and retaining qualified employees.

basis_points.basis_description: Supermarkets have become a significant substitute for traditional liquor stores as more states relax alcohol sale laws, providing convenience for customers purchasing groceries and alcohol in one trip.

basis_points.basis_title: Rise of DIY alcoholic beverage production
basis_points.basis_description: DIY alcoholic beverage production is rising, spurred by a growing interest in home brewing, winemaking and distilling, accelerated during the coronavirus pandemic, driving demand for DIY kits and supplies.

Online sales are promoting industry consolidation and expansion as e-commerce enables stores to reach broader audiences, prompting smaller retailers to merge for efficiency or invest in digital infrastructure.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Regulations keep liquor stores small scale
concentration_points.concentration_description: Regulatory frameworks often limit the number of liquor licenses, restrict locations for alcohol sales through zoning laws, and impose high compliance costs, favoring smaller local businesses over large chains.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Online sales promote consolidation and expansion
concentration_points.concentration_description: The rise in online sales enables beer, wine and liquor stores to reach broader audiences, encouraging consolidation to maximize efficiency and expand market presence through mergers and integrations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the largest expense for liquor stores
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: To remain competitive, liquor stores must offer a wide selection of alcohol or specialize in a specific kind of beverage offering, resulting in a substantial share of revenue allocated toward purchases.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Expansion into E-Commerce Platforms Benefits Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The coronavirus accelerated beer, wine and liquor stores' entrance into the online space, as few small and medium-sized retailers had e-commerce presences prior to the pandemic.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Remain a Key Expense Despite Automated Operations
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Beer, wine and liquor stores are labor-intensive, with personnel needed to stock shelves, manage inventory and provide customer service.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Liquor stores require substantial labor to stock shelves, manage inventory and provide customer service. Finding and retaining qualified employees can be a challenge.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE PANDEMIC INTRODUCED THE FIRST REVENUE DECLINES IN MORE THAN A DECADE
volatility_points.volatility_description: As bars and restaurants closed amid the coronavirus, consumers turned to beer, wine and liquor stores to meet their alcoholic beverage needs, resulting in surging sales, particularly during the pandemic's peak.
With inflation on the rise, the cost of alcohol has gone up. This can be attributed to an increase in the cost of key inputs and supply chain disruptions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ONLINE ORDERING APPEALS TO A NEW GENERATION OF DRINKERS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: In eligible states, many liquor stores have adopted online ordering and delivery services, allowing customers to order their favorite drinks from the comfort of their own homes.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TASTING EVENTS ENHANCE THE CUSTOMER EXPERIENCE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Tasting events at liquor stores allow customers to sample new and different products before making a purchase. Liquor stores have increasingly relied on these events to attract new consumers.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Offering a variety of products, including those not often found at alternative retailers, can attract a wider consumer base. State regulations are typically more stringent for selling spirits, making them harder to find outside of industry establishments. Operators who specialize in spirits may have a competitive advantage and may experience higher profit.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Historically, alcohol sales are not typically significantly hampered by economic fluctuations.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators compete for skilled employees to serve an increasingly knowledgeable customer base, including food and wine pairing hobbyists and craft beer aficionados. Training and incentives are critical for retaining top talent.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs comprise the largest share of industry revenue for industry companies.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators can use point-of-sale (POS) software to monitor inventory levels, automatically stock shelves, automate their purchasing costs and operate a streamlined checkout process.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales?
FAQs.answer: Online sales, which are excluded from the industry, have been on the rise as states have continued to deregulate alcohol sales. Competition from online alcohol services is expected to continue rising in the outlook period.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory changes significantly impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: Deregulation often boosts access to industry products. As more external competitors, like supermarkets and wholesale clubs, have begun selling alcohol and using their large operations to secure low prices from alcohol suppliers, some industry operators have had to lower prices to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Associations such as the Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America provide operators with advocacy, publicity, educational and social responsibility services and programs.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit compare with your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit is relatively low across the industry, although larger companies may experience higher profit if they can secure lower prices from suppliers.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare with major competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Keeping shelves stocked with the latest and most popular products can help ensure a quick inventory turnover rate.

FAQs.question: What is your reputation with regard to prices? How can you appeal to more budget-conscious clients? How do you stay competitive?
FAQs.answer: Due to low industry profit, companies must ensure they offer an appropriate mix of high-turnover products and slightly more expensive products.

FAQs.question: Are you located near major suppliers? How can you reduce your company's transportation costs?
FAQs.answer: Owners must ensure that ongoing and reliable shipments are available from the wholesaler to keep stock levels in line with demand, especially during periods of elevated inventory turnover.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What factors influence demand and stock levels?
FAQs.answer: It's important for industry operators to regularly monitor stock levels to ensure steady sales of all brands with little overstock.

FAQs.question: How have excise taxes trended in the states in which you operate? What portion of excise taxes are you able to pass on to consumers?
FAQs.answer: There are 17 states that directly operate all spirits sales and generate revenue from various taxes, fees and licensing dues, while the remaining states have varying degrees of privatization along the supply chain.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor per capita expenditure on alcohol? Do you sell premium-priced alcohol?
FAQs.answer: As individuals increase their alcohol consumption, per capita expenditure on alcohol typically increases. Changes in consumer attitudes often affect the sale of alcoholic beverages.

FAQs.question: Which of your products experience strengthened demand when consumer incomes rise? How can you take advantage of strengthening per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: When per capita disposable income rises, consumers are more likely to spend on discretionary goods like alcohol and particularly high-end products.
